image.altText: A woman with long brown hair leans on an iron fence next to a highway with a large truck driving on it.

props.synopsis: Murrumbateman residents express significant safety concerns about the Barton Highway and repeated calls for it to be duplicated after another fatality on the road this week.

title.children: Murrumbateman locals sick of 'bandaid' Barton Highway safety solutions

image.altText: Three identical teenaged boys stand in a line smiling in the stands of a sporting stadium.

props.synopsis: One of the St Edmund's College boys seriously injured after being hit by an allegedly stolen car on the way to school is petitioning the ACT government to put a pedestrian bridge over the road where he was hit.

title.children: Canberra boy hit by car outside school calls for pedestrian overpass

image.altText: An ACT ambulance driving along a road *good generic

props.synopsis: For several hours this week, there were only four ambulances capable of transporting stretchered patients on Canberra's roads. The ideal number in operation is nine.

title.children: 'A lot of good luck': Just four ACT stretchered ambulances in operation one night this week

image.altText: The portait shows three young people appearing to play outside.

props.synopsis: An image of three First Nations girls gesturing with their middle fingers towards the camera, highlighting the issue of Indigenous children in youth detention, wins the National Photographic Portrait Prize.

title.children: Portrait prize winner highlights plight of Indigenous youth detainees

image.altText: A woman with short brown hair and glasses stands outdoors looking serious.

props.synopsis: The ACT government changes its plans for a Canberra school expansion after data showed they expected fewer enrolments than had been predicted during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.children: Canberra school dismayed after $50 million expansion walked back

image.altText: A man with short brown hair wearing a red and blue checkered shirt speaks with his hands in front of a courthouse

props.synopsis: Mike Worsman was aged 12 when he was sexually abused in the 1990s in Canberra. He says the system's let him down.

title.children: 'Mere 16 months of peace': Survivor angered by abuser's sentence

image.altText: ANU signage with Genevieve Bell and Julie Bishop

props.synopsis: The prestige of the Australian National University is fast fading. It must now respond to explosive allegations.

title.children: How one of the world's most prestigious universities fell from grace

image.altText: A graphic of a house being dropped on a conveyor belt.

props.synopsis: From early colonial settlers to the post-war construction boom, prefabricated and modular housing has a long history in Australia. Can factory-built homes fix our housing woes and help the climate?

title.children: There's a solution to build the housing we need, but we need to embrace it

image.altText: A woman holds balls of rice to the camera.

props.synopsis: Amid severe shortages and pressure from Donald Trump's "reciprocal tariffs", Japan is under unprecedented pressure to eat more foreign rice. Here's why that's controversial.

title.children: Japan's rice crisis sparks debate over food security and identity

image.altText: dreame-x40

props.synopsis: A major Chinese robot vacuum maker's smartphone app has a critical security flaw leaving it susceptible to leaking user data and credentials if targeted by hackers.

title.children: Robot vacuum maker Dreame's smartphone app vulnerable to hacking

image.altText: Alex Lloyd leans his chin on his hand, resting on the top of his guitar.

props.synopsis: In 2001, Alex Lloyd broke through with his massive hit Amazing, a song that led to the best and then the worst time of his life. Now he's getting his life back on track.

title.children: Champagne, fast food and opioids: Alex Lloyd reveals the reality of rock bottom

image.altText: Lauren Jackson arrives for the Sport Australia Hall of Fame, posing on the red carpet in a black evening dress

props.synopsis: For some it's about money, for others it's regaining fame or relevance. For basketball star Lauren Jackson the decision to step out of retirement had nothing to do with either reason, and instead was all down to a happy accident. Getting back to super star fitness level was no easy task though.

title.children: Money, pressure and fame: Why elite athletes step out of retirement

image.altText: a large group of tents in gaza city sit on top of rubble and in front of destroyed buildings

props.synopsis: Gaza residents will be provided with tents and other shelter equipment starting from Sunday ahead of relocating them from combat zones to "safe" ones in the south of the enclave, the Israeli military said.

title.children: Israeli military prepares to relocate residents to southern Gaza

image.altText: A naked man and woman lean on a fence.

props.synopsis: When you think of nudism, you might picture postcard-perfect beaches or serene forests. But what about swathes of rugged Queensland bush, where the only neighbours are cattle herds and coal mines?

title.children: Thongs the only requirement at this bush weekender turned nudist haven

image.altText: Man shakes hands with a robotic prosthetic

props.synopsis: Australia's decline in productivity, and falling business investment, has policymakers worried. It's why they're meeting in Canberra this week.

title.children: What is productivity? If we can do more with less effort, we all benefit

image.altText: A graphic of books and age classifications such as G, PG, M and MA 15+ restricted.

props.synopsis: The growing influence of BookTok, BookTube and Bookstagram has a researcher concerned about the content young people are engaging with, and they are calling for an industry-wide book rating classification system.

title.children: Films and video games have age classifications. Should books?

image.altText: RACQ Map

props.synopsis: The RACQ calls for urgent government reform as Queensland Road Safety Week begins, with 2025 on track to be one of the most dangerous years for drivers.

title.children: New map reveals deadliest crash hotspots as experts, families demand action

image.altText: A woman on a beach offers a treat to one dog as two others look on

props.synopsis: SA residents are turning to expensive muzzles to protect their pets from the algae crisis so they can keep walking them on the beach.

title.children: Dog owners find costly solutions to keep pets safe from toxic algal bloom

image.altText: Tom Gleeson on the set of Hard Quiz gesturing behind him with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Ah, back again I see. I do admire your courage for giving it another go … just kidding, I never feel that way.

title.children: Put your trivia know-how to the test. I dare you

image.altText: A group of police officers in yellow vests scuffle with people dressed in black in a city street.

props.synopsis: There were hostile scenes in Melbourne's CBD several blocks from where a Women's Voices Australia rally was being held.

title.children: Counter-protesters, police clash at rally held in Melbourne

image.altText: Three men walk around debris and rubble holding parts of damaged houses

props.synopsis: Hundreds of people are dead in north-west Pakistan after two days of intense rain and floods, with rescue efforts and clearing of blocked roads increased with the release of emergency funds.

title.children: 'Doomsday' monsoon rain and floods leave hundreds dead in Pakistan

image.altText: A map of qld showing a red dot where the earthquake was.

props.synopsis: Geoscience Australia is reporting the earthquake was centred roughly 250 kilometres north of Brisbane.

title.children: 'Lucky' magnitude-5.6 quake 'didn't hit closer to towns', seismologist says

image.altText: An electronic stock ticker board at the ASX, with lines in green and red.

props.synopsis: With the Reserve Bank in their corner promising to ensure market stability, are investors playing with the very concept of risk?

title.children: Central bank cash a backstop for investors but it can't last forever

props.synopsis: Tributes flow for former Australian skipper and coach Bob Simpson after the cricket legend died aged 89.

title.children: 'No-one gave more to Australian cricket': Legends pay tribute to Simpson

image.altText: An Adelaide AFL coach and a Crows midfielder shake hands and smile at each other on the ground after a win over Collingwood.

props.synopsis: Adelaide coach Matthew Nicks says the lid may be off in South Australia but it remains firmly in place at the headquarters of his AFL ladder-leaders despite their thrilling win over Collingwood.

title.children: The lid is not on in South Australia after Magpies win, says Crows coach

image.altText: A rugby league player in yellow socres a try

props.synopsis: The Broncos beat the Dolphins in a 10-try Battle of Brisbane as South Sydney urges fans not to invade the pitch to celebrate Alex Johnston's record-breaking try, a decision slammed as "dumb" by Penrith and Cronulla great Luke Lewis.

title.children: Broncos score 'one of the tries of the season' to win classic Battle of Brisbane

image.altText: A rakali perched on a rock eating a shellfish.

props.synopsis: Whether it's hunting invasive pests or rolling in a river like an otter, there's a lot to love about the rakali. And a lot of Australians love it.

title.children: How the rebranded rakali went from giant rat to a new Aussie icon

image.altText: A silver sedan with a dent in its passenger side door parked in a dirt car park in front of bushland.

props.synopsis: A 48-year-old man will face court on Sunday charged with murdering a man who was found injured next to his car in a Perth car park in April.

title.children: Man charged with murder over mysterious death of father found lying in car park

image.altText: A large brown bear dripping with water in a river.

props.synopsis: Japanese police said the man in his 20s was hiking at Mount Rausu, on the northern island of Hokkaido, on Thursday morning when he was attacked.

title.children: Hiker dead after bear attack on walking trail in northern Japan

image.altText: A head shot of a smiling man. A palm tree next to him.

props.synopsis: Court documents detail the movements of Graeme Davidson in the days after his wife Jacqueline died in 2020.

title.children: After his wife died, Graeme Davidson went home to burn documents, court records allege

image.altText: Kirralie Smith smiling with bushland in the background.

props.synopsis: An anti-transgender rights activist has lost her right to appeal an apprehended violence order taken out by a transgender woman, after "highly intimidatory", "objectively harassing," and "unnecessarily cruel" X posts.

title.children: Anti-trans activist loses AVO appeal after 'highly intimidatory' X posts

image.altText: Showers spread through Melbourne on Friday as the first of two cold fronts arrived.

props.synopsis: This weekend will bring some of the coldest weather of the season, as a two-pronged pulse of polar air sweeps well north.

title.children: La Niña watch issued as eastern Australia braces for more rain, snow

image.altText: Robin Miller stands beside a plane.

props.synopsis: A tiny plane once used to deliver medical care across the Western Australian outback has returned to Broome for the first time in decades to honour its original pilot Robin Miller.

title.children: How a young nurse flew tiny plane to deliver remote medical care in the 1960s
